bioml.note: DEFAULT PARAMETERS. The value of "isb_default_input_kscore.xml" is recommended. Change to "isb_default_input_native.xml" for native X!Tandem scoring.

FILE LOCATIONS. Replace them with your input (.mzXML) file and output file -- these are REQUIRED. Optionally a log file and a sequence output file of all protein sequences identified in the first-pass can be specified. Use of FULL path (not relative) paths is recommended.
TAXONOMY FILE. This is a file containing references to the sequence databases. Point it to your own taxonomy.xml if needed.

PROTEIN SEQUENCE DATABASE. This refers to identifiers in the taxomony.xml, not the .fasta files themselves! Make sure the database you want is present as an entry in the taxonomy.xml referenced above. This is REQUIRED.
PRECURSOR MASS TOLERANCES. In the example below, a 10ppm (monoisotopic mass) window is searched for peptide candidates.

This allows peptide candidates in windows around -1 Da and -2 Da from the acquired mass to be considered. Only applicable when the minus/plus window above is set to less than 0.5 Da. Good for accurate-mass instruments for which the reported precursor mass is not corrected to the monoisotopic mass.

MODIFICATIONS. In the example below, there is a static (carbamidomethyl) modification on C, and variable modifications on M (oxidation). Multiple modifications can be separated by commas, as in "80.0@S,80.0@T". Peptide terminal modifications can be specified with the symbol '[' for N-terminus and ']' for C-terminus, such as 42.0@[ .

You can specify a variable modification only when present in a motif. For instance, 0.998@N!{P}[ST] is a deamidation modification on N only if it is present in an N[any but P][S or T] motif (N-glycosite).
These are *static* modifications on the PROTEINS' N or C-termini.
SEMI-TRYPTICS AND MISSED CLEAVAGES. In the example below, semitryptic peptides are allowed, and up to 2 missed cleavages are allowed.

REFINEMENT. Do not use unless you know what you are doing. Set "refine" to "yes" and specify what you want to search in the refinement. For non-confusing results, repeat the same modifications you set above for the first-pass here.
